question: A 67-year-old man with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus presents to the ED with severe chest pain. The pain started suddenly a few hours ago, characterized as sharp and radiating to his back. He has never experienced pain like this before. He also has been sweaty, short of breath, and nauseous, but denies cough, fever, vomiting, or a history of trauma. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes per day since age 15, and currently takes lisonopril, amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. In the ED, his temperature is 98.5 deg F (36.9 deg C), blood pressure is 85/50 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 25/min. An EKG is seen in Figure A and appears similar to an EKG obtained 1 month ago. He appears to be in moderate distress. Auscultation of his chest revealed no murmurs and his lungs are clear bilaterally. There is no tenderness to palpation along his chest wall. His abdominal exam is noteworthy for a pulsatile mass. The rest of his exam is within normal limits. Appropriate management is initiated. What is the most likely etiology of this patient's acute chest pain?

This patient presents with sudden, severe, sharp chest pain radiating to the back, hypotension, tachycardia, and a pulsatile abdominal mass. His EKG shows no acute ischemic changes compared to prior, and lung exam is clear. These findings strongly suggest an acute aortic dissection, likely involving the descending thoracic aorta and extending into the abdominal aorta (explaining the pulsatile abdominal mass).

question: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurring of vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. What is the most likely cause for this patient's symptoms?
options: A. Infarct of the right middle cerebral artery B. Infarct of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery C. Infarct of the right posterior cerebral artery D. Infarct of the right anterior cerebral artery E. Herpes simplex encephalitis F. Infarct of the left middle cerebral artery G. Infarct of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery H. Infarct of the left anterior cerebral artery I. Infarct of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery J. Infarct of the left posterior cerebral artery K. Infarct of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery L. Ophthalmic migraine
solution_text: Infarct of the left posterior cerebral artery

question: A 9-year-old girl presents with dyspnea, palpitations, joint pain, and fever for the past week. She says that her symptoms started 2 weeks ago with bilateral knee pain which has shifted to both ankles over the past week. She says she noticed bilateral leg swelling since yesterday. Her vital signs include: respiratory rate 22/min, temperature 37.7°C (100.0°F), blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, and SpO2 88% on room air. question:
An 18-year-old girl comes to the emergency room with abdominal pain. She states that the pain started 6 hours ago, is 8/10, and localizes to the right lower abdomen. She recalls a similar episode last month. Her older brother was hospitalized 2 years ago for perforated appendicitis. Her mother has diverticulitis. The patient got her first menstrual period at age 14. Her periods occur regularly every 28 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. The patient’s temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, and respirations are 14/min with an oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. On physical exam, the patient is in moderate distress. There is lower abdominal tenderness with guarding. A pelvic examination reveals clear mucous in the vaginal introitus, a mobile uterus, and tenderness of the right adnexa. Labs are obtained, as shown below:

Leukocyte count: 10,000/mm^3 with normal differential

question: A 23-year-old gravida-1-para-1 (G1P1) presents to the emergency department with fever, malaise, nausea, and abdominal pain. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has had 3 sexual partners in the past month and uses oral contraception. Uterine and adnexal tenderness is also elicited. A urine pregnancy test is negative. On speculum examination, the cervix is inflamed with positive cervical motion tenderness and the presence of a scant yellow-white purulent discharge. question:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and hydrochlorothiazide. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:
Serum
Na+ 126 mEq/L
K+ 3.6 mEq/L
Cl- 107 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 16 mg/dL
Glucose 87 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Osmolality 255 mOsmol/kg H2O
Urine
Osmolality 523 mOsmol/kg H2O
Sodium 44 mEq/L
What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?"
options: A. Cerebral salt wasting syndrome B. Hydrochlorothiazide C. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone D. Opioid overdose E. Primary polydipsia F. Mineralocorticoid deficiency
default:
This patient presents with hyponatremia (Na+ 126 mEq/L), low serum osmolality (255 mOsm/kg), inappropriately concentrated urine (urine osmolality 523 mOsm/kg), and elevated urine sodium (44 mEq/L) after recent brain surgery (meningioma resection). She has symptoms of confusion, fatigue, muscle cramps, nausea, and vomiting.

The key features are:
- Hyponatremia with hypo-osmol

Your conclusion is correct. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

question: A 37-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a chief complaint of diarrhea. The patient states that his symptoms have worsened recently. He works as a farmer and is dressed in tattered and old denim. He lives alone, and this is the first time he has come to town in years. The patient’s diet is mostly dairy products and some meat products. He denies any systemic symptoms and states that diarrhea tends to occur right after a meal. He also claims that at times he struggles to fall asleep, and sometimes he feels he lacks energy. The patient is instructed to avoid consuming dairy products for a week and to return with a report of his symptoms. As you set up the return appointment with this patient you notice that he is rather emotionless. He also states that he lacks anybody that he can list as an emergency contact so he leaves that section of his medical forms blank. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Antisocial personality disorder B. Avoidant personality disorder C. Major depressive disorder D. Schizoid personality disorder E. Schizotypal personality disorder
default:
The patient's symptoms—postprandial diarrhea (especially after dairy), fatigue, difficulty sleeping, and a diet heavy in dairy and meat—along with his social isolation and poor hygiene, suggest lactose intolerance or malabsorption. However, the key clue is that diarrhea occurs right after meals, especially dairy, and improves with dairy avoidance, indicating lactose intolerance.

The patient's diarrhea occurring after meals, especially with a diet high in dairy, and improvement after avoiding dairy products point toward lactose intolerance. His emotional flatness and social isolation may be related to his lifestyle but do not fulfill criteria for schizoid personality disorder based on the information provided.

The most likely diagnosis is lactose intolerance.

Reasoning: The patient's diarrhea occurs right after meals, especially given his diet rich in dairy products, which suggests malabsorption of lactose. His emotional flatness and social isolation may reflect his lifestyle but do not necessarily indicate a primary psychiatric disorder like antisocial personality disorder. The key clinical clue is postprandial diarrhea linked to dairy consumption, consistent with lactose intolerance.

The most likely diagnosis is lactose intolerance.

Reasoning: The patient's diarrhea occurs after meals, especially given his diet rich in dairy products, and improves when dairy is avoided, which is characteristic of lactose intolerance. The emotional flatness and social isolation may be secondary but are not the primary diagnosis here.

question: A 25-year-old man comes to the emergency department with right knee pain. He was playing soccer when an opposing player tackled him from the side and they both fell down. He immediately heard a popping sound and felt severe pain in his right knee that prevented him from standing or walking. On physical examination, his right knee is swollen and there is local tenderness, mostly at the medial aspect. External rotation of the right knee elicits a significant sharp pain with a locking sensation. What structures is most likely injured?
options: A. Anterior cruciate ligament B. Posterior cruciate ligament C. Medial collateral ligament D. Medial meniscus tear E. Lateral meniscus tear
default: The clinical presentation suggests a medial meniscus tear. The mechanism (a lateral tackle causing a twisting injury), immediate popping sound, swelling, medial knee tenderness, pain with external rotation, and locking sensation are classic signs of a medial meniscal injury.
raw_a:
The most likely injured structure is the medial meniscus. 

Reasoning: A lateral force causing a valgus stress with external rotation commonly injures the medial meniscus, especially when there is a popping sound, severe pain, swelling, tenderness on the medial side, and locking of the knee. The medial collateral ligament injury usually causes pain and tenderness medially but less commonly causes locking or a popping sound.
raw_b:
The most likely injured structure is the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL).

Reasoning: The mechanism described—a lateral tackle causing a sudden valgus force with external rotation, an immediate popping sound, severe pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight—is classic for an ACL tear. While medial meniscus tears can cause pain and locking, they usually result from twisting injuries but less commonly present with an immediate pop and rapid swelling. The external rotation pain and locking can also be due to associated meniscal
raw_c:
The most likely injured structures are the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and the medial meniscus.

Reasoning: The mechanism—side tackle with a popping sound, immediate severe pain, swelling, inability to bear weight, and locking with pain on external rotation—suggests an ACL injury often accompanied by a medial meniscus tear. The medial tenderness and locking are typical of medial meniscus involvement, while the instability and popping sound point to ACL rupture.
raw_d:
The most likely injured structure is the medial meniscus.

Reasoning: The mechanism—lateral force causing a valgus stress with external rotation—commonly injures the medial meniscus and medial collateral ligament (MCL). However, the presence of a popping sound, immediate severe pain, swelling, tenderness mostly at the medial aspect, and especially the locking sensation with pain on external rotation strongly points to a medial meniscus tear rather than an isolated MCL injury. MCL injuries typically cause medial pain

question: A previously healthy 56-year-old woman comes to the family physician for a 1-month history of sleep disturbance and sadness. Several times she has been woken up by the sound of her husband calling her name. She has lost 3 kg (6.6 lb) over the past month. She has 3 children with whom she still keeps regular contact and regularly attends church services with her friends. She expresses feeling a great feeling of loss over the death of her husband. She has no suicidal ideation. She is alert and oriented. Neurological exam shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms?
options: A. Schizoaffective disorder B. Normal bereavement C. Acute stress disorder D. Major depressive disorder E. Adjustment disorder with depressed mood

The most likely diagnosis is **normal bereavement (complicated grief is less likely here)**.

She maintains social connections and has no suicidal ideation or significant functional impairment, which argues against major depressive disorder.

Blood 2+
RBC 20–30/hpf

Bacteria none

A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with respiratory distress, fever, and a productive cough. Past medical history is significant for a history of recurrent bronchopneumonia since the age of 5, managed conservatively with antibiotics and mucolytic therapy. The patient’s weight was normal at birth, but he suffered from a failure to thrive, although there was no neonatal history of chronic diarrhea or jaundice. His current vitals are a respiratory rate of 26/min, a pulse of 96/min, a temperature of 38.8℃ (101.8°F), a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. On physical examination, there is coarse crepitus bilaterally and both expiratory and inspiratory wheezing is present. The chest radiograph shows evidence of diffuse emphysema. A sweat chloride test and nitro tetrazolium test are both within normal limits. A complete blood count is significant for the following:
WBC 26300/mm3
Neutrophils 62%
Lymphocytes 36%
Eosinophils 2%
Total bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.2 mg/dL
SGOT 100 U/L
SGPT 120 U/L
ALP 200 U/L

options: A. Cystic fibrosis B. Kartagener syndrome C. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency D. Wilson’s disease E. Chronic granulomatous disease

question: A 7 -day-old newborn boy presents to the emergency department with a history of fever, irritability, and generalized erythema. During the first 2 days of clinical manifestations, the parents of the child tried to control the symptoms using acetaminophen; however, the newborn continued to be ill, and blisters were noticeable around the buttocks, hands, and feet. During the physical examination, the vital signs include body temperature 39.0°C (102.3°F), heart rate 130/min, and respiratory rate 45/min. Ears, nose, and oral mucosa preserved their integrity, while the skin presents with diffuse blanching erythema and flaccid blisters with a positive Nikolsky’s sign. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: A. Scarlet fever B. Scalded skin syndrome C. Impetigo D. Erysipela E. Pyoderma
default: The most likely diagnosis is Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS). This condition typically affects neonates and young children and presents with fever, irritability, diffuse erythema, flaccid blisters, and a positive Nikolsky’s sign due to exfoliative toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus. The preservation of mucous membranes helps differentiate it from conditions like toxic epidermal necrolysis.

question: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department with epigastric pain. The patient states that he was at home watching television when his symptoms began. Otherwise, the patient has no complaints. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, hypertension, alcohol abuse, diabetes, and constipation. His current medications include insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and sodium docusate. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values and an abdominal ultrasound are ordered and are currently pending. An abdominal radiograph is ordered as seen in Figure A. On physical exam, the patient is clinically intoxicated. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The patient is started on IV fluids and given morphine. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Choledocholithiasis B. Acute cholecystitis C. Adenocarcinoma of the gallbladder D. Acute pancreatitis E. Nephrolithiasis
default:
Based on the presentation of a 57-year-old man with epigastric pain, a history of alcohol abuse, and an abdominal radiograph (though the image is not provided here), the most likely diagnosis is **acute pancreatitis**.

question: A 23-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for knee pain. The pain started yesterday and has not improved since then. The patient is generally in good health. She attends college and plays soccer for her school's team. Three days ago, she was slide tackled during a game and her leg was struck from the outside. She fell to the ground and sat out for the rest of the game. It was not until yesterday that she noticed swelling in her knee. She also feels as if her knee is unstable and does not feel confident bearing weight on her leg during athletic activities. Her past medical history is notable for asthma, which is currently treated with an albuterol inhaler. On physical exam, you note bruising over her leg, knee, and lateral thigh, and edema of her knee. question: A 35-year-old man is pulled out of a burning building. He is unconscious and severely injured. He is transported to the nearest emergency department. Upon arrival, he is stabilized and evaluated for burns and trauma. Approximately 40% of his body is covered in burns. The burned areas appear blackened and charred but the skin is mostly intact. It is noted that the patient has loss of pain sensation in the burnt areas with minimal blanching on palpation. The affected area is soft to when palpated. What category of burn did the patient most likely to suffer from?
options: A. Superficial (1st degree) B. Deep-partial thickness (3rd degree) C. Full-thickness (4th degree) D. Superficial-partial thickness (2nd degree) E. Electric burn
default: The patient most likely suffered a full-thickness (third-degree) burn. This is characterized by blackened, charred skin that is mostly intact, loss of pain sensation due to nerve destruction, minimal blanching, and a soft or leathery texture on palpation.
raw_a:
The patient most likely suffered a full-thickness (3rd degree) burn. 

Reasoning: Blackened, charred skin with loss of pain sensation and minimal blanching indicates destruction of both the epidermis and dermis, including nerve endings. The skin being soft rather than firm suggests full-thickness damage rather than deep partial-thickness, which is typically firm and leathery. Therefore, this presentation is consistent with a full-thickness (3rd degree) burn.

The patient most likely suffered a full-thickness (third-degree) burn.

These burns destroy both the epidermis and dermis, including nerve endings, leading to loss of pain sensation. Electric burns typically have different features and are not described primarily by the skin appearance alone.
raw_d:
The patient most likely suffered a full-thickness (third-degree) burn. 

Reasoning: The description of blackened, charred skin with mostly intact skin, loss of pain sensation, minimal blanching, and a soft texture is characteristic of full-thickness burns. Deep partial-thickness burns (second-degree) usually have blistering, are painful, and have some preserved sensation. Electric burns can cause deep tissue damage but the clinical description here fits classic full-thickness thermal burns.

question: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of blindness in her right eye that suddenly started 1 hour ago. She has no feeling of pain, pressure, or sensation of a foreign body in the right eye. She has a history of major depressive disorder treated with fluoxetine. The patient attends college and states that she has had a lot of stress lately due to relationship problems with her partner. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. She appears anxious. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmologic examination shows a normal-appearing eye with no redness. Slit lamp examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. question: A 34-year-old woman, who had her first child 2 weeks ago, visits her family physician with concerns about constant fatigue and difficulty with breastfeeding. She was discharged from the intensive care unit after hospitalization for severe postpartum hemorrhage. Since then, she has tried multiple pumps and self-stimulation to encourage breast milk production; however, neither of these strategies has worked. Her blood pressure is 88/56 mm Hg and heart rate is 120/min. What best explains the underlying condition of this patient?
options: A. Pituitary infarction B. Pituitary stalk epithelial tumor C. Pituitary infection D. Pituitary hemorrhage E. Pituitary infiltration by histiocytes
default: This patient likely has Sheehan's syndrome, which is postpartum hypopituitarism due to ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage. The severe blood loss leads to hypovolemic shock and pituitary infarction, causing deficiency of pituitary hormones including prolactin, resulting in failure of lactation. Her hypotension, tachycardia, fatigue, and inability to breastfeed after massive hemorrhage support this diagnosis.

A pituitary stalk epithelial tumor is unrelated to the acute postpartum setting and hemorrhage.

question:

He also has associated dizziness, blurring of vision, and palpitations. He has had similar episodes over the last 6 months but none this severe. He has not had fever, weight change, or loss of appetite. He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 18. His father died of renal cancer. He is diaphoretic. Hemoglobin 14.8 g/dL

question: An 84-year-old man presents to the emergency department for a loss of consciousness. The patient states that he was using the bathroom when he lost consciousness and fell, hitting his head on the counter. A 64-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a fall. The patient states that he has felt abnormally clumsy lately and has noticed himself tripping and bumping into things. He states he otherwise is healthy but admits to having unprotected sex with multiple people recently. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Hematocrit: 30%
Mean corpuscular volume: 110 fL
Leukocyte count: 6,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3
AST: 15 U/L
ALT: 22 U/L

question:
A 34-year-old woman presents with confusion, drowsiness, and headache. The patient’s husband says her symptoms began 2 days ago and have progressively worsened with an acute deterioration of her mental status 2 hours ago. The patient describes the headaches as severe, localized to the frontal and periorbital regions, and worse in the morning. Review of symptoms is significant for a mild, low-grade fever, fatigue, and nausea for the past week. Past medical history is significant for HIV infection for which she is not currently receiving therapy. Her CD4+ T cell count last month was 250/mm3. The blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg, the pulse rate is 90/min, and the temperature is 37.7°C (100.0°F). On physical examination, the patient is conscious but drowsy. Papilledema is present. No pain is elicited with extension of the leg at the knee joint. The remainder of the physical examination is negative. Laboratory findings, including panculture, are ordered. A noncontrast CT scan of the head is negative and is followed by a lumbar puncture. CSF analysis is significant for:
Opening pressure 250 mm H2O (70-180 mm H2O)
Glucose 30 mg/dL (40-70 mg/dL)
Protein 100 mg/dL (<40 mg/dL)
Cell count 20/mm3 (0-5/mm3)
What additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?
options: A. CSF shows a positive acid-fast bacillus stain B. CSF shows gram negative diplococci C. CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells D. Gram-positive diplococci are present on microscopy E. Multiple ring-enhancing lesions are seen on a CT scan
solution_text: CSF India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells
default:
This patient with HIV (CD4 count 250), subacute headache, confusion, papilledema, elevated opening pressure, low CSF glucose, elevated protein, and mild pleocytosis suggests cryptococcal meningitis.

Additional findings likely include:

- India ink stain positive for encapsulated yeast (Cryptococcus neoformans) in CSF
- Positive cryptococcal antigen test in CSF and serum
- Possibly gelatinous pseudocysts on brain imaging (MRI)
- CSF culture
alternative: Multiple ring-enhancing lesions are seen on a CT scan
raw_a:
The most likely diagnosis is cryptococcal meningitis in an HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 250 and signs of increased intracranial pressure (papilledema, elevated opening pressure). However, the CSF findings (low glucose, elevated protein, mild pleocytosis) and subacute presentation could also suggest tuberculous meningitis or fungal infection.

Given the negative noncontrast CT and the clinical picture, the next step would be contrast-enhanced imaging. In cryptococcal mening
raw_b:
The most likely diagnosis is cryptococcal meningitis in an HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 250/mm³, presenting with subacute headache, confusion, papilledema, elevated opening pressure, low CSF glucose, elevated protein, and mild pleocytosis.

The additional finding most likely to be present is **CSF India ink stain showing encapsulated yeast cells (Cryptococcus neoformans)**.

Reasoning: Cryptococcal meningitis is common in immunocompromised
raw_c:
The most likely diagnosis is cryptococcal meningitis in an HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 250 and symptoms of subacute headache, confusion, papilledema, elevated opening pressure, low CSF glucose, elevated protein, and mild pleocytosis. 

Additional findings would include: 
- Positive India ink stain showing encapsulated yeast (Cryptococcus neoformans)
- Positive cryptococcal antigen test in CSF
- Possibly elevated CSF opening pressure due to increased intracran
raw_d: The clinical presentation and CSF findings (elevated opening pressure, low glucose, elevated protein, mild pleocytosis) in an HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 250 suggest a subacute meningoencephalitis rather than multiple brain abscesses. The noncontrast CT is negative, which is typical before lumbar puncture in meningitis. Cryptococcal meningitis is common in HIV patients and presents with these CSF findings; India ink stain would reveal encapsulated yeast

Lymphocytes 94%

question: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the neurologist for management of recently diagnosed seizures. Based on her clinical presentation, the neurologist decides to start a medication that works by blocking thalamic T-type calcium channels. Her parents are cautioned that the medication has a number of side effects including itching, headache, and GI distress. Specifically, they are warned to stop the medication immediately and seek medical attention if they notice skin bullae or sloughing. What conditions is most likely being treated in this patient?
options: A. Absence seizures B. Complex seizures C. Simple seizures D. Status epilepticus E. Tonic-clonic seizures
default:
The patient is most likely being treated for absence seizures. 

Ethosuximide is the medication that blocks thalamic T-type calcium channels and is the first-line treatment for absence seizures in children. The side effects described—including itching, headache, GI distress, and the risk of severe skin reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome (skin bullae and sloughing)—are characteristic warnings associated with ethosuximide.

question: A 5-year-old boy is brought in by his mother for ear discharge. His mother reports that the patient was in his usual state of health until two weeks ago when he developed a “cold,” with a cough and sinusitis. She reports that his symptoms have since resolved. Then two days ago, the patient started to complain that his left ear felt “full.” His mother reports she tried to clean his ear out with a cotton swab. Then this morning, his mother noticed foul-smelling ear discharge coming from his left ear. His past medical history is significant for asthma and recurrent otitis media. The patient’s temperature is 97°F (36.1°C), blood pressure is 110/63 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 22/min with an oxygen saturation of 99% O2 on room air. Upon visual examination of the patient's left ear you appreciate Figure A. During pneumatic otoscopy, the mass does not move with the tympanic membrane. What is the most likely explanation for these findings?
options: A. Acute otitis media B. Cholesteatoma C. Foreign body D. Tympanic membrane rupture E. Tympanosclerosis
default:
The clinical presentation of a 5-year-old with recent upper respiratory infection, followed by ear fullness and foul-smelling ear discharge, along with a mass seen behind the tympanic membrane that does not move with pneumatic otoscopy, is most consistent with a cholesteatoma.

Cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous epithelial cysts that can develop in the middle ear, often as a complication of chronic or recurrent otitis media. They present as a white mass behind the tympanic membrane
raw_a:
The most likely diagnosis is a cholesteatoma, not tympanosclerosis. 

Reasoning: The history of recent upper respiratory infection followed by ear fullness and foul-smelling discharge suggests a chronic middle ear process. The presence of a mass behind the tympanic membrane that does not move with pneumatic otoscopy indicates a lesion in the middle ear space. Tympanosclerosis typically presents as white, calcified plaques on the tympanic membrane without associated foul discharge or a mass effect. In contrast,
raw_b: The most likely diagnosis is a foreign body in the external auditory canal rather than a cholesteatoma. The key clues are the foul-smelling ear discharge, the history of the mother cleaning the ear with a cotton swab, and the mass seen on otoscopy that does not move with the tympanic membrane during pneumatic otoscopy. Cholesteatomas typically arise from the middle ear and cause a retraction pocket or mass behind the tympanic membrane that moves with it, whereas a foreign body in
raw_c:
The most likely diagnosis is acute otitis externa with impacted cerumen and secondary infection.

Reasoning: The child had a recent upper respiratory infection, followed by ear fullness and foul-smelling discharge. The mother attempted to clean the ear with a cotton swab, which can cause trauma and introduce infection to the external auditory canal. The mass seen on otoscopy that does not move with the tympanic membrane suggests impacted cerumen or debris in the external canal rather than a middle ear pathology. The foul-sm
raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is cholesteatoma, not tympanosclerosis. 

Reasoning: The key features are foul-smelling ear discharge, a history of recurrent otitis media, and a mass behind the tympanic membrane that does not move with pneumatic otoscopy. Cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous epithelial growths that can develop as a complication of chronic or recurrent middle ear infections. question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with concern for a rash. The patient states he has an odd rash on his legs that have not been improving. The patient has a past medical history of a recent myocardial infarction which was appropriately treated, diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia. He has a family history of prostate cancer, Parkinson disease, and depression. His temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 177/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 34 mg/dL
Glucose: 177 mg/dL
Creatinine: 2.2 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL

What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Arterial insufficiency B. Atheroembolism C. Congestive heart failure D. Medication reaction E. Venous insufficiency
default:
The patient has a rash on his legs and lab values showing elevated BUN and creatinine, indicating acute or chronic kidney injury. Given his history of diabetes, hypertension, recent MI, and the rash, a likely diagnosis is **calciphylaxis** (calcific uremic arteriolopathy).

Calciphylaxis typically occurs in patients with end-stage renal disease or significant kidney dysfunction, often with secondary hyperparathyroidism, and presents as painful purpuric or necrotic skin
raw_a:
The most likely diagnosis is atheroembolism.

Reasoning: The patient has a history of recent myocardial infarction and multiple cardiovascular risk factors (diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia), which predispose to atherosclerotic disease. The rash on the legs, likely livedo reticularis or blue toe syndrome (as suggested by the physical exam image), along with acute kidney injury (elevated creatinine and BUN) and stable electrolytes, supports cholesterol crystal embolization

The most likely diagnosis is **calciphylaxis** (calcific uremic arteriolopathy).

Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes, hypertension, recent MI, and now presents with a non-healing rash on the legs. His labs show elevated BUN and creatinine, indicating significant renal impairment (likely chronic kidney disease). The rash in calciphylaxis typically presents as painful, violaceous plaques or necrotic ulcers on the lower extremities, often in patients
raw_c:
Apologies for the confusion. Given the patient's history of diabetes, hypertension, recent MI, elevated blood pressure, elevated BUN and creatinine indicating kidney dysfunction, and a rash on the legs (likely purpura or livedo reticularis), the most likely diagnosis is **calciphylaxis** or **vasculitis related to chronic kidney disease**.

However, without the image, the best fit is **diabetic nephropathy with secondary skin changes such as necrobiosis lipo
raw_d:
You are correct; the most likely diagnosis is atheroembolism. 

Reasoning: The patient has a history of recent myocardial infarction and vascular risk factors (diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia), along with a rash on the legs that is not improving. The elevated creatinine and BUN suggest acute or subacute kidney injury. Atheroembolism (cholesterol crystal embolism) commonly occurs after vascular interventions or in patients with severe atherosclerosis, causing livedo

Additionally, radiography of her shoulder showed several 'punched-out' areas of lytic bone. question: A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of one episode of vomiting and severe headache since this morning. His mother says he also had difficulty getting dressed on his own. He has not had any trauma. The patient appears nervous. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 185/125 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is an abdominal bruit that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle. A complete blood count is within normal limits. What is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
options: A. Echocardiography B. Oral sodium loading test C. CT angiography D. Serum IGF-I level E. Serum PTH level F. High-dose dexamethasone suppression test G. Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone level H. Urinary catecholamine metabolites
default:
This 10-year-old boy presents with severe hypertension (BP 185/125), headache, vomiting, confusion, bilateral optic disc swelling (papilledema), and an abdominal bruit at the right costovertebral angle. These findings suggest hypertensive encephalopathy due to secondary hypertension.

In a child, severe hypertension with an abdominal bruit strongly suggests renovascular hypertension, most commonly due to renal artery stenosis. The bruit at the right costovertebral angle supports renal artery involvement.

To confirm
raw_a: The most likely diagnosis is hypertensive encephalopathy due to renovascular hypertension, suggested by severe hypertension, abdominal bruit, and neurological symptoms. The best test to confirm this diagnosis is renal artery Doppler ultrasound or CT angiography to identify renal artery stenosis. Since CT angiography provides detailed vascular imaging, it is indeed the most appropriate confirmatory test.
raw_b:
The most likely diagnosis is hypertensive encephalopathy due to secondary hypertension from renal artery stenosis, suggested by the severe hypertension, abdominal bruit at the right costovertebral angle, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, vomiting, confusion, bilateral optic disc swelling). 

To confirm the diagnosis, the best test is **renal artery Doppler ultrasound or renal artery imaging (CT or MR angiography)** to identify renal artery stenosis. Serum PTH level is not relevant here
raw_c:
The most likely diagnosis is hypertensive encephalopathy due to secondary hypertension, possibly from renal artery stenosis (suggested by the abdominal bruit at the right costovertebral angle). The severe hypertension, headache, vomiting, confusion, and bilateral optic disc swelling (papilledema) indicate increased intracranial pressure from malignant hypertension.

To confirm the diagnosis, **renal artery Doppler ultrasound or renal angiography** would be most appropriate to identify renal artery stenosis causing secondary hypertension.

raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is hypertensive encephalopathy due to secondary hypertension, suggested by severe hypertension, headache, vomiting, confusion, bilateral papilledema, and an abdominal bruit. The abdominal bruit points toward renovascular hypertension, most commonly caused by renal artery stenosis.

Therefore, the test most likely to confirm the diagnosis is **CT angiography** (or MR angiography) of the renal arteries to identify renal artery stenosis.

Serum PTH is not relevant here; the key is imaging

question:
A 45-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department by the police. He was found intoxicated and passed out in a library. The patient has a past medical history of IV drug abuse, diabetes, alcohol abuse, and malnutrition. The patient has been hospitalized previously for multiple episodes of pancreatitis and sepsis. Currently, the patient is minimally responsive and only withdraws his extremities in response to painful stimuli. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 90/48 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical exam is notable for tachycardia, a diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border, and bilateral crackles on pulmonary exam. The patient is started on IV fluids, vancomycin, and piperacillin-tazobactam. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below.

Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL

Glucose: 100 mg/dL

Ca2+: 9.0 mg/dL
PT: 40 seconds
aPTT: 90 seconds
AST: 150 U/L
ALT: 90 U/L

What is the best description of this patient’s current status?
options: A. Recovery from acute alcoholic liver disease B. Recovery from ischemic liver disease C. Recovery from acute renal failure D. Acute renal failure E. Fulminant liver failure
default:
This patient initially presented with sepsis (tachycardia, hypotension, elevated liver enzymes, coagulopathy) likely due to infective endocarditis (diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border suggests tricuspid or pulmonic valve involvement, common in IV drug users). Initial labs showed elevated PT/aPTT, elevated transaminases, acute kidney injury, and mild anemia.

raw_a:
The best description of this patient’s current status is **acute liver failure with developing coagulopathy and improving transaminases**.

Reasoning: The patient initially presented with very high AST and ALT levels (>900 U/L), indicating acute severe hepatocellular injury. Over 5 days, transaminases have decreased significantly but remain elevated, which is typical in acute liver injury as hepatocytes die and enzyme release declines. raw_b:
The best description of this patient’s current status is **acute liver failure complicated by disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)**.

Reasoning: Initially, the patient presented with markedly elevated AST and ALT (>900 U/L), indicating acute severe hepatocellular injury (acute liver failure). His initial coagulopathy (PT 20 sec, aPTT 60 sec) worsened over 5 days (PT 40 sec, aPTT 90 sec), despite some improvement in
raw_c:

Reasoning: Initially, the patient presented with markedly elevated AST and ALT (over 900 U/L), indicating acute severe liver injury, likely from ischemic hepatitis ("shock liver") given his hypotension and tachycardia. His coagulation studies were prolonged initially (PT 20 sec, aPTT 60 sec) and worsened

question:

question: A 55-year-old obese woman is referred to the cardiology clinic for progressive dyspnea. She has had no recent travel or sick contacts. Besides a multivitamin, she has only tried online weight-loss medications for the past five years, including fenfluramine-phentermine. An echocardiogram reveals a dilated right ventricle with systolic pressure of 60 mmHg as well as both tricuspid and pulmonary regurgitation. A right heart catheterization shows a mean pulmonary artery pressure of 40 mmHg. What disease process is most analogous to this patient's presentation?
options: A. Subacute endocarditis B. Carcinoid syndrome C. Chronic thromboembolic disease D. Left heart failure E. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

While carcinoid syndrome can cause right-sided valvular heart disease, it typically leads to plaque-like fibrosis of the valves rather than primary pulmonary hypertension with elevated pulmonary artery pressures

This morning, his cough acutely worsened prompting him to seek care. question: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dizziness. He states he has experienced a sustained sensation of the room spinning that is low grade and constant since this morning. The patient occasionally feels nauseous and has been taking diphenydramine to sleep which helps with his symptoms. The patient is generally healthy, has no other medical conditions, and only endorses eating more garlic recently to get over a cold he had a few days ago. His temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 122/81 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a healthy man. The patient is sat upright, his head is turned slightly to the right, and he is laid back flat rapidly. This does not provoke any symptoms even when repeated on the left side. A nystagmus is notable on cranial nerve exam as well as bilateral decreased hearing. The patient’s tandem gait is unstable; however, his baseline gait appears unremarkable despite the patient stating he has a sustained sensation of imbalance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo B. Labyrinthitis C. Meniere disease D. Vertebrobasilar stroke E. Vestibular neuritis
default:
The most likely diagnosis is **bilateral vestibular neuritis (or labyrinthitis)**.

Explanation:
- The patient has a sustained, low-grade vertigo (room spinning) with nausea.
- No positional provocation of symptoms or nystagmus on Dix-Hallpike maneuvers, which argues against benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
- Bilateral decreased hearing and nystagmus suggest involvement of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve

raw_c:

These findings suggest a bilateral peripheral vestibular problem rather than an acute unilateral vestibular neuritis or labyrinthitis, which typically cause severe vertigo and unilateral hearing loss. The bilateral hearing loss and nystagmus point toward a bilateral

The most likely diagnosis is Meniere disease. 

This patient has a sustained sensation of vertigo, bilateral hearing loss, and imbalance, which are characteristic of Meniere disease. Labyrinthitis typically presents with acute vertigo and unilateral hearing loss, often following an infection, but bilateral hearing loss and chronic symptoms point more toward Meniere disease

question: A 22-year-old man presents to a psychiatrist complaining of mood fluctuations. question:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his daughter for a 1-week history of right leg weakness, unsteady gait, and multiple falls. During the past 6 months, he has become more forgetful and has sometimes lost his way along familiar routes. He has been having difficulties operating simple kitchen appliances such as the dishwasher and the coffee maker. He has recently become increasingly paranoid, agitated, and restless. He has HIV, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His last visit to a physician was more than 2 years ago, and he has been noncompliant with his medications. His temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F), blood pressure is 152/68 mm Hg, pulse is 98/min, and respirations are 14/min. He is somnolent and slightly confused. He is oriented to person, but not place or time. There is mild lymphadenopathy in the cervical, axillary, and inguinal areas. Neurological examination shows right lower extremity weakness with normal tone and no other focal deficits. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 3600/mm3
Platelet count 140,000/mm3
CD4+ count 56/μL

Serum
Cryptococcal antigen negative
Toxoplasma gondii IgG positive

question:
A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient is non-verbal at baseline, but his caretakers at the nursing home noticed he was particularly somnolent recently. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and Alzheimer dementia. His temperature is 99.7°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 157/98 mmHg, pulse is 150/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are obtained and shown below.

Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL
Hematocrit: 33%
Leukocyte count: 8,500/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 197,000/mm^3

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 102 mEq/L
K+: 4.3 mEq/L
HCO3-: 25 mEq/L
BUN: 37 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 2.4 mg/dL
Ca2+: 12.2 mg/dL

The patient has lost 20 pounds over the past month. His parathyroid hormone is within normal limits, and his urinary calcium is increased. Physical exam demonstrates discomfort when the patient's lower back and extremities are palpated. What is the most accurate diagnostic test for this patient's underlying diagnosis?
options: A. Bone marrow biopsy B. Peripheral blood smear C. Radiograph of the lumbar spine D. Urine, blood, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures E. Urine protein levels
default:
This patient presents with altered mental status, hypercalcemia (Ca2+ 12.2 mg/dL), anemia, elevated creatinine (2.4 mg/dL), weight loss, and bone pain (discomfort on palpation of lower back and extremities). His PTH is normal (not elevated), and urinary calcium is increased, which rules out primary hyperparathyroidism and suggests a non-PTH mediated hypercalcemia.

raw_a:
The most accurate diagnostic test for this patient’s underlying diagnosis is a **skeletal survey (X-rays of the bones)** or **serum and urine protein electrophoresis with immunofixation**, but ultimately a **bone marrow biopsy** is required for definitive diagnosis.

Reasoning: This elderly patient presents with hypercalcemia, anemia, renal dysfunction, weight loss, and bone pain—all classic features of multiple myeloma. Normal PTH and increased urinary calcium exclude primary hyperparathyroidism.

The most accurate diagnostic test for this patient's underlying diagnosis is a **skeletal survey (X-rays of the bones)** or a **bone marrow biopsy**.

Reasoning: The patient has hypercalcemia with normal PTH, increased urinary calcium, anemia, elevated creatinine, weight loss, and bone pain—all classic features of multiple myeloma. Multiple myeloma causes lytic bone lesions leading to bone pain and hypercalcemia. The best diagnostic test is a skeletal survey to identify lytic
raw_c:
The most accurate diagnostic test is a skeletal survey (X-rays of the bones).

Reasoning: This patient has hypercalcemia with normal PTH, increased urinary calcium, anemia, elevated creatinine, weight loss, bone pain, and altered mental status—classic features of multiple myeloma. The best diagnostic test to confirm multiple myeloma is a skeletal survey to identify lytic bone lesions. Additional tests include serum and urine protein electrophoresis, but the skeletal survey is key for diagnosis.
raw_d:
The most accurate diagnostic test for this patient is a **bone marrow biopsy**.

Reasoning: The patient has hypercalcemia with normal PTH, increased urinary calcium excretion, anemia, elevated creatinine, weight loss, and bone pain—all classic features of multiple myeloma. Bone marrow biopsy is the definitive test to diagnose multiple myeloma by demonstrating clonal plasma cell infiltration.

question: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of increasing pain and swelling in her right foot for the past 2 weeks. question: A 65-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by his wife for slurred speech and right-sided weakness. The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The wife reports her husband went to bed last night normally but woke up this morning with the symptoms mentioned. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis along with the loss of vibration and proprioception. Cranial nerve examination shows a deviated tongue to the left. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Medial pontine syndrome B. Lateral pontine syndrome C. Dejerine syndrome D. Wallenberg syndrome E. Weber syndrome
default:

This syndrome results from occlusion of the anterior spinal artery affecting the medial medulla, causing contralateral hemiparesis (due to corticospinal tract involvement), contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue deviation (hypoglossal nerve nucleus or fibers). question: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of watery discharge from her right eye for 2 weeks. She and her parents, who are refugees from Sudan, arrived in Texas a month ago. question: A 69-year-old woman presents to the emergency department in severe abdominal pain. Over the last five days days, she has developed watery diarrhea and has been in almost constant pain which has now increased to an intensity of 10/10. On exam, her vitals are T 102.3F, HR 125, BP 89/45, RR 20. She has pain with palpation along her lower quadrants with questionable guarding. question: A 45-year-old man with a history of epilepsy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has had trouble moving the right side of his body for 2 weeks. question: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her husband complaining, “I can’t see out of my right eye.” She was watching television last night when she covered her left eye due to an itch and discovered that she could not see. The patient denies any precipitating event, pain, swelling, flashes, floaters, or headaches. Her past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and angina. Her medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and nitroglycerin as needed. Her physical examination is unremarkable. Fundus examination demonstrates generalized pallor and slight disc edema with no hemorrhages. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
options: A. Acute increase in pressure of the eye B. Detachment of the retina C. Inflammation of the temporal artery D. Occlusion of the ophthalmic artery by embolus E. Optic neuritis
solution_text: Occlusion of the ophthalmic artery by embolus
default:

Given her history of uncontrolled hypertension and angina, the most likely diagnosis is ischemic optic neuropathy, specifically non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION).

question:
A 72-year-old man presents to the ED complaining of worsening abdominal pain over the last few hours. He also reports nausea, but denies fever, vomiting, or changes in the appearance of his bowel movements. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and peptic ulcer disease. Due to his recurrent bleeding peptic ulcers, he does not take warfarin. His surgical history is significant for an appendectomy as a child. His medications include metformin, lisinopril, metoprolol, and omeprazole. He has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. His temperature is 37.6 C (99.7 F), blood pressure is 146/80 mm Hg, pulse is 115/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. On physical exam, he is in acute distress due to the pain. Pulmonary auscultation reveals scattered wheezes and decreased air entry. His heart rate is irregularly irregular, with no murmurs, rubs or gallops. question: A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of repeated episodes of severe headache for the past 3 days. He is currently having his 2nd episode of the day. He usually has his first episode in the mornings. The pain is severe and localized to his right forehead and right eye. He had similar symptoms last summer. He works as an analyst for a large hedge fund management company and spends the majority of his time at the computer. He has been under a lot of stress because of overdue paperwork. He also has chronic shoulder pain. He has been using indomethacin every 6 hours for the pain but has had no relief. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He appears restless. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows drooping of the right eyelid, tearing of the right eye, and rhinorrhea. The right pupil is 2 mm and the left pupil is 4 mm. There is localized tenderness to his right supraspinatus muscle. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question: A 27-year-old-man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a motorcycle accident. He lost control at high speed and was thrown forward onto the handlebars. On arrival, he is alert and responsive. He has abdominal pain and superficial lacerations on his left arm. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tender, erythematous area over his epigastrium. The abdomen is soft and non-distended. A CT scan of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Treatment with analgesics is begun, the lacerations are cleaned and dressed, and the patient is discharged home after 2 hours of observation. Four days later, the patient returns to the emergency department with gradually worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, poor appetite, and vomiting. His pulse is 91/min and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Pancreatic ductal injury B. Liver hematoma C. Aortic dissection D. Abdominal compartment syndrome E. Diaphragmatic rupture F. Splenic rupture
default:
The most likely diagnosis is pancreatic injury with delayed presentation of pancreatitis or pancreatic necrosis. 

Explanation: The patient had a high-speed motorcycle accident with direct blunt trauma to the epigastrium (thrown onto handlebars), which is a classic mechanism for pancreatic injury. Initial CT scan can often miss pancreatic trauma, especially early on, because pancreatic injuries may not be immediately apparent. The delayed onset of worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and systemic signs several days later suggests development of pancreatic inflammation

The most likely diagnosis is pancreatic ductal injury. 

This patient had blunt abdominal trauma with epigastric tenderness and initially normal imaging, but now presents days later with worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting—classic signs of a delayed pancreatic injury. Pancreatic ductal injuries often have subtle early findings and can be missed on initial CT scans, leading to delayed symptoms as pancreatic enzymes leak and cause inflammation or infection.

The most likely diagnosis is delayed pancreatic injury with pancreatic duct disruption.

Reasoning: The patient had blunt abdominal trauma from a motorcycle accident with epigastric tenderness but a normal initial CT scan. Pancreatic injuries, especially ductal injuries, can be missed early on imaging and present days later with worsening abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and systemic signs due to pancreatic inflammation or developing pancreatitis. The delayed presentation and symptoms fit a pancreatic injury rather than aortic dissection, which would present more
raw_d:
The most likely diagnosis is pancreatic ductal injury.

Reasoning: The patient had blunt abdominal trauma with epigastric tenderness but a normal initial CT scan, which can miss pancreatic injuries early on. The delayed onset of worsening upper abdominal pain, fever, vomiting, and systemic signs after a few days is characteristic of pancreatic injury with ductal disruption leading to inflammation, possible pancreatic fluid leakage, and secondary infection. Aortic dissection is unlikely given the mechanism, presentation, and location of symptoms.

question: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for sudden joint pain. She states that the pain started several hours ago and has been worsening. The pain is localized to the knee and is preventing her from walking. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and was in a car accident 1 week ago. She is currently taking insulin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 99.4°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 137/78 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a hot and painful right knee. The patient is unable to demonstrate her gait on exam. Passive range of motion elicits severe pain in the right knee. A radiograph is ordered as seen in Figure A. What is most likely also to be seen in this patient?
options: A. Cartilage degeneration on arthroscopy B. Increased neutrophils with positive culture results on arthrocentesis C. Negatively birefringent crystals on arthrocentesis D. Positive circulating anti-CCP antibodies E. Rhomboid crystals on arthrocentesis
default:
The clinical presentation of sudden onset of a hot, swollen, and painful knee with inability to bear weight, along with severe pain on passive range of motion, strongly suggests septic arthritis. The patient's recent trauma (car accident) and diabetes increase her risk for joint infection.

Although the radiograph image is not provided here, in septic arthritis, plain films may show joint effusion but are often normal early on. Over time, joint space narrowing and bone erosions can develop.

raw_a: The most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis given the acute onset of severe knee pain, joint warmth, and inability to bear weight, especially in a patient with diabetes and recent trauma. The radiograph may show joint effusion but is often nonspecific. Septic arthritis typically shows purulent synovial fluid with a high white cell count and positive bacterial cultures on arthrocentesis, not rhomboid crystals. Rhomboid crystals are characteristic of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (pseudogout
raw_b:
The most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis, given the acute onset of severe knee pain, joint warmth, inability to bear weight, and systemic signs in a patient with diabetes and recent trauma. The radiograph (though not visible here) likely shows joint effusion without chronic degenerative changes. 

Therefore, what is most likely also to be seen is **a high white blood cell count in synovial fluid with positive bacterial cultures**, indicating infection. Cartilage degeneration is a feature of chronic osteoarthritis,

The radiograph likely shows joint effusion or soft tissue swelling but may be normal early on. Septic arthritis is often accompanied by elevated white blood cell count in synovial fluid, positive Gram stain or culture, and systemic signs of infection. Given her diabetes (a risk factor) and recent trauma, septic arthritis is the
raw_d: The most likely diagnosis is pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease), given the acute monoarticular arthritis in the knee of an older adult with a recent stressor (trauma from car accident). The radiograph typically shows chondrocalcinosis (linear calcifications in cartilage). Therefore, the most likely finding on arthrocentesis is rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals.

question:

question: A 32-year-old woman presents complaining of nightmares. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes a day but denies alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient appears slightly anxious but is in no acute distress. A physical and neurological exam is normal. question: A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department for right wrist pain and swelling 2 hours after falling on an outstretched hand while playing softball. question: A 17-year-old girl suddenly grabs her chest and collapses to the ground while playing volleyball at school. The teacher rushes to evaluate the situation and finds that the girl has no pulse and is not breathing. He starts chest compressions. An automated external defibrillator (AED) is brought to the scene within 3 minutes and a shock is delivered. The girl regains consciousness and regular sinus rhythm. She is rushed to the emergency department. The vital signs include: blood pressure 122/77 mm Hg and pulse 65/min. The pulse is regular. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows a shortened PR interval, a wide QRS complex, a delta wave, and an inverted T wave. What is the most likely pathology in the conduction system of this patient’s heart?
options: A. Automatic discharge of irregular impulses in the atria B. Impulse generation by tissue in atrioventricular node C. Wandering atrial pacemaker D. Accessory pathway from atria to ventricles E. Blockage in conduction pathway
solution_text: Accessory pathway from atria to ventricles
default:
The ECG findings of a shortened PR interval, wide QRS complex with a delta wave, and inverted T waves are characteristic of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. WPW is caused by the presence of an accessory atrioventricular (AV) conduction pathway (the bundle of Kent) that bypasses the normal AV node conduction system, leading to pre-excitation of the ventricles.

Therefore, the most likely pathology in this patient’s conduction system is an accessory AV pathway

The most likely pathology is the presence of an accessory pathway causing Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. 

Reasoning: The ECG findings of a shortened PR interval, wide QRS complex, and delta wave are classic for WPW, which involves an abnormal accessory conduction pathway (the bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node. This can lead to episodes of tachyarrhythmia and sudden cardiac arrest, explaining the collapse and need for defibrillation. It is
raw_b:
The most likely pathology is an accessory pathway from atria to ventricles, consistent with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.

Reasoning: The ECG findings—shortened PR interval, wide QRS complex with a delta wave, and inverted T waves—are classic for WPW syndrome, which involves an accessory atrioventricular pathway (the bundle of Kent) that bypasses the AV node. This can lead to reentrant tachyarrhythmias and sudden cardiac arrest
raw_c: Yes, the most likely pathology is the presence of an accessory pathway causing Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. The ECG findings of a shortened PR interval, wide QRS complex with a delta wave, and inverted T waves are classic for WPW. This accessory pathway allows abnormal conduction from atria to ventricles, predisposing to reentrant tachyarrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac arrest, especially during exertion like playing volleyball.
raw_d:
The most likely pathology is an accessory pathway (such as in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome), not a blockage. 

Reasoning: The ECG findings—shortened PR interval, wide QRS complex with a delta wave, and inverted T waves—are classic for pre-excitation due to an accessory pathway bypassing the AV node. question: A 39-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of increasing shortness of breath over the past 3 months. He has been unable to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment. question: A 28-year-old male presents to trauma surgery clinic after undergoing an exploratory laparotomy, femoral intramedullary nail, and femoral artery vascular repair 3 months ago. He suffered multiple gunshot wounds as a victim of a drive-by shooting. He is progressing well with well-healed surgical incisions on examination. He states during his clinic visit that he has been experiencing 6 weeks of nightmares where he "relives the day he was shot." The patient also endorses 6 weeks of flashbacks to "the shooter pointing the gun at him" during the daytime as well. He states that he has had difficulty sleeping and cannot concentrate when performing tasks. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Acute stress disorder B. Normal reaction to trauma C. Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) D. Schizophrenia E. Schizophreniform disorder
default: The patient's symptoms of nightmares, flashbacks, difficulty sleeping, and impaired concentration following a traumatic event (gunshot wounds) are characteristic of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).
raw_a: The most likely diagnosis is Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). The patient's history of a traumatic event (gunshot wounds), along with symptoms of nightmares, flashbacks, difficulty sleeping, and concentration problems lasting for more than one month, are characteristic of PTSD rather than schizophrenia.
raw_b: The most likely diagnosis is Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The patient's symptoms—nightmares reliving the traumatic event, daytime flashbacks, difficulty sleeping, and impaired concentration—are classic features of PTSD, which typically develops after exposure to a life-threatening event such as a shooting. The timing (symptoms persisting for more than one month) and symptom cluster align with PTSD diagnostic criteria, making it the most appropriate diagnosis.
raw_c: Yes, the most likely diagnosis is post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The patient has experienced a traumatic event (gunshot wounds from a drive-by shooting) and now has symptoms lasting more than one month, including nightmares, flashbacks, difficulty sleeping, and impaired concentration, all characteristic of PTSD.
raw_d: The most likely diagnosis is still post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), not schizophrenia. The patient's symptoms—nightmares, flashbacks of the traumatic event, difficulty sleeping, and trouble concentrating—are classic features of PTSD following a traumatic experience like a shooting. Schizophrenia typically involves symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, and negative symptoms, which are not described here.

question:
A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 35 weeks estimated gestational age presents with a headache for the past 5 hours. She describes the headache as severe and incapacitating and showing no response to acetaminophen. In the emergency department, her blood pressure is found to be 150/100 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). Her records show that her blood pressure was the same yesterday during her regular antenatal visit. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles along the lung base. Abdominal examination reveals a gravid uterus consistent with a gestational age of 32 weeks and a floating fetus in a cephalic presentation. Pelvic examination is performed which shows a closed firm cervix with no evidence of bleeding or discharge. Moderate pitting edema is noted and neurologic examination shows generalized hyperreflexia. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL
Platelets 185,000/μL
Serum creatinine 0.4 mg/dL
Spot urine creatinine 110 mg/dL
Spot urine protein 360 mg/dL
AST 40 IU/L
What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
options: A. HELLP syndrome B. Preeclampsia with severe features C. Preeclampsia without severe features D. Eclampsia E. Gestational hypertension
default:

question: A 43-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained passenger. question: A 60-year-old African American male with a history of AIDS presents to the emergency room complaining of a headache. He reports a two-week history of progressively worsening diffuse headache, nausea, vomiting, fever, and confusion. His past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and major depressive disorder. He takes metformin, glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, sertraline, and anti-retroviral therapy but admits to not taking his medications regularly. He has a history of intravenous drug use and a 25 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 100.6°F (38.1°C), blood pressure is 150/85 mmHg, pulse is 115/min, and respirations are 20/min. Physical examination reveals mild neck stiffness. Strength, sensation, and reflexes are normal in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally. Findings from a stained blood smear are shown in Figure A. A brain MRI and lumbar puncture are planned. What findings on brain MRI is most consistent with this patient’s condition?

question: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of a “curtain” suddenly obscuring her vision in her right eye. She reports for the past few weeks, she has experienced intermittent episodes of seeing flashes of light as well as floaters blocking her visual field. She denies any eye pain or irritation. question: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He states that his symptoms started a few days ago and have been gradually worsening. question: A 59-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a sudden-onset sensation that the room is spinning causing him to experience several episodes of nausea and vomiting. Upon arriving, the patient’s symptoms have resolved. He states his symptoms occurred as he was going to bed. He has never experienced this before, but felt extremely dizzy for roughly 3 minutes. He currently feels at his baseline. The patient is otherwise healthy and only has a history of eczema. His temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 134/85 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a healthy man with a normal gait. The patient has a physiologic nystagmus and his cranial nerve exam is unremarkable. The patient’s head is turned to the left and he is laid back on the stretcher, which exacerbates severe symptoms with a nystagmus notable. The patient’s symptoms improve after 2 minutes of being in this position. What is the most likely diagnosis?

question: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a dry cough and severe chest pain beginning that morning. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with inferior wall myocardial infarction and was treated with stent implantation of the right coronary artery. He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, and enalapril. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound best heard while sitting upright and during expiration. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows diffuse ST elevations. Serum studies show a troponin I of 0.2 ng/mL (N < 0.01). What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
options: A. Cardiac tamponade B. Constrictive pericarditis C. Aortic dissection D. Reinfarction E. Early infarct-associated pericarditis F. Dressler syndrome G. Pulmonary embolism
default:
This patient presents 2 months after an inferior MI with fever, pleuritic chest pain, a pericardial friction rub, diffuse ST elevations on ECG, and mildly elevated troponin. These findings are classic for Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction pericarditis), an autoimmune-mediated pericarditis occurring weeks to months after MI.

Key points:
- Timing: Occurs weeks to months post-MI.
- Symptoms: Pleuritic chest pain, fever.

question: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of high-grade fever and generalized fatigue for 5 days. Two days ago, he developed a rash on his trunk. He returned from a family hiking trip to Montana 1 week ago. His immunization records are unavailable. His temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with skin lesions. The patient states that he has felt itchy recently, then noticed skin lesions that broke out this morning prompting him to come to the emergency department. The patient states that he recently went camping and hiking in the woods. The patient drinks 1-2 beers per day and smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. He is currently sexually active with multiple partners and does not use condoms. The patient was discharged 1 week ago for pneumonia which was treated with azithromycin; however, he feels that his symptoms may be returning. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 157/78 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. question: A 72-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of lethargy and weakness for the past 5 days. During this period, she has had a headache that worsens when she leans forward or lies down. Her arms and face have appeared swollen over the past 2 weeks. She has a history of hypertension and invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast. She underwent radical amputation of the left breast followed by radiation therapy 4 years ago. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. Current medications include aspirin, hydrochlorothiazide, and tamoxifen. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 98/56 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention, a mastectomy scar over the left thorax, and engorged veins on the anterior chest wall. There is no axillary or cervical lymphadenopathy. There is 1+ pitting edema in both arms. What is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
options:
A. Hodgkin lymphoma B. Pulmonary tuberculosis C. Pulmonary embolism D. Constrictive pericarditis E. Lung cancer F. Nephrotic syndrome
"
default:
This patient has signs and symptoms consistent with superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome: headache worse when leaning forward or lying down (increased venous pressure), facial and arm swelling, jugular venous distention, and engorged chest wall veins. Her history of left breast cancer treated with surgery and radiation, along with heavy smoking, puts her at risk for malignancy-related SVC obstruction.

The most likely cause is obstruction of the superior vena cava due to external compression or thrombosis.

question: One day after undergoing total knee replacement for advanced degenerative osteoarthritis, a 66-year-old man has progressive lower abdominal pain. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia and the patient was temporarily catheterized for perioperative fluid balance. Several hours after the surgery, the patient began to have decreasing voiding volumes, nausea, and progressive, dull lower abdominal pain. He has Sjögren syndrome. He is sexually active with his wife and one other woman and uses condoms inconsistently. He does not smoke and drinks beer occasionally. Current medications include pilocarpine eye drops. He appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a pelvic mass extending to the umbilicus. It is dull on percussion and diffusely tender to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9,000/mm3, a platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An attempt to recatheterize the patient transurethrally is unsuccessful. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
options:
A. Cystolithiasis B. Benign prostatic enlargement C. Adverse effect of pilocarpine D. Acute prostatitis E. Urethral stricture F. Neurogenic bladder G. Prostate cancer

question: A 67-year-old man presents with a large, painful, skin lesion on his leg (Figure A). He has had a non-healing ulcer in the same location for several years after a burn, but he notes that it has never looked like this before. He has a past medical history of diabetes. He is a 30-pack-year smoker. Vital signs are stable. In addition to the skin lesion, his physical examination is notable for stocking glove neuropathy of the hands and feet. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Melanoma B. Basal cell carcinoma C. Actinic keratosis D. Squamous cell carcinoma E. Psoriasis
default: The most likely diagnosis is a Marjolin ulcer, which is a squamous cell carcinoma arising in a chronic non-healing ulcer or scar, such as a burn scar. The patient's history of a chronic ulcer at the site of a previous burn, now presenting as a large, painful, and changing lesion, strongly supports this diagnosis. The stocking-glove neuropathy is likely related to his diabetes and is a separate finding.
